docs.snippet: A European ban on practically all imports of American meat has angered United States officials, brought threats of reprisal and caused a general scratching of heads here.    The dispute comes as the European Community and Washington are locked in...
docs.lead_paragraph: A European ban on practically all imports of American meat has angered United States officials, brought threats of reprisal and caused a general scratching of heads here. The dispute comes as the European Community and Washington are locked in battle over billions of dollars of farm subsidies, which the United States has pressed to reduce sharply.

headline.main: Europe's Ban on U.S. Meat Is Threatening Trade Talks

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: A group of leading agricultural-trading nations said today that unless the European Community immediately presented proposals to cut farm subsidies, the entire four-year round of world trade talks might be in jeopardy.   "Unless significant progress...
docs.lead_paragraph: A group of leading agricultural-trading nations said today that unless the European Community immediately presented proposals to cut farm subsidies, the entire four-year round of world trade talks might be in jeopardy. "Unless significant progress is achieved by mid-November, all participants in the negotiations would need to assess the implications for the further conduct of the round, and for the future of the entire multilateral trading system," the group said in a statement issued after a one-day meeting here. Its 14 members are Australia, Argentina, Brazil, Canada, Chile, Colombia, Fiji, Hungary, Indonesia, Malaysia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Thailand and Uruguay. Deadlock in Brussels In Brussels, European Community farm and trade ministers met for the seventh time to try to agree on proposals to present in Geneva. But they failed tonight to break a deadlock and adjourned until Tuesday.

headline.main: Agricultural Exporters Tell Europeans to Bend

docs.snippet: American trade officials said today the Brussels agreement should forestall an untimely collapse of the Uruguay Round, but they insisted it would have to be sweetened considerably to serve as a basis for future farm negotiations.   A Bush...
docs.lead_paragraph: American trade officials said today the Brussels agreement should forestall an untimely collapse of the Uruguay Round, but they insisted it would have to be sweetened considerably to serve as a basis for future farm negotiations. A Bush Administration trade official said the proposed cutback in the community's farm spending was "inadequate," but he added, "If it means they are ready to talk now, that's a good sign."

headline.main: Europeans Reach Accord on Farm Aid; Tepid Reaction in U.S.

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: The European Community's agreement on the terms of a proposal for cutting barriers to farm trade was greeted with cautious enthusiasm tonight at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the 105-nation organization that is responsible for the...
docs.lead_paragraph: The European Community's agreement on the terms of a proposal for cutting barriers to farm trade was greeted with cautious enthusiasm tonight at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the 105-nation organization that is responsible for the Uruguay Round of world trade liberalization talks. A GATT spokesman said there would "certainly be some relief" that all the major negotiating groups now have an offer on the table. But the spokesman added there would be a need to look at the fine print in some detail. There would also need to be an assurance that there was some room for negotiation, he said. A large gap remains to be bridged between the American proposal, submitted three weeks ago, for 90 percent cuts in export subsidies and 75 percent in other farm supports, and the community proposal for 30 percent cuts. The news came from Brussels as five days of crisis meetings at the Geneva headquarters of GATT and among some of the main participants had ended without any clear sign of progress. The four-year-long Uruguay Round is scheduled to end in Brussels Dec. 7. GATT's Director General, Arthur Dunkel of Switzerland, said with evident disappointment that there were not many signs of movement. Rubens Ricupero of Brazil, speaking for the developing countries, also said there had been no real negotiating effort in Geneva, and no progress in areas like agriculture and textiles that are of particular importance to developing countries. He warned that these countries would not accept a package worked out by other nations that is presented on a "take it or leave it" basis. The chief United States negotiator, Warren Lavorel, told the meeting: "I came here to strike deals, not to make speeches. So let's get on with it."

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE

docs.snippet: After five weeks of wrangling about the future of small farmers, the members of the European Community agreed tonight that reductions in agricultural subsidies should be part of their negotiating position in the current round of worldwide talks aimed...
docs.lead_paragraph: After five weeks of wrangling about the future of small farmers, the members of the European Community agreed tonight that reductions in agricultural subsidies should be part of their negotiating position in the current round of worldwide talks aimed at freer trade. Although purposely vague, the European position generally backs what would in effect be a 30 percent cut in both price supports and tariffs on farm imports in the 10-year period under negotiation, which is retroactive to 1986 and extends to 1996.

headline.main: Europeans Reach Accord On Farm Aid

byline.original: By PAUL L. MONTGOMERY, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: A 14-nation bloc of farm exporting countries said today that world trade talks might collapse unless the European Community changes its proposal on cutting agriculture subsidies.   "A negotiation which showed no movement away from the current...
docs.lead_paragraph: A 14-nation bloc of farm exporting countries said today that world trade talks might collapse unless the European Community changes its proposal on cutting agriculture subsidies. "A negotiation which showed no movement away from the current European Community offer would be totally unacceptable," said Neal Blewett, chairman of the Cairns Group. Mr. Blewett, Australia's foreign trade minister, called the community proposal for a 30 percent cut in subsidies over 10 years "very disappointing." Cairns officials said they welcomed assurances from the top European trade official Frans Andriessen, that the community proposal was an opening position, not a final offer. But they said they worried that it did not allow negotiators room to offer deeper cuts. The members of the Cairns Group are Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Canada, Chile, Colombia, Fiji, Hungary, Indonesia, Malaysia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Thailand and Uruguay.

docs.snippet: ONE big reason for the angry mood of many voters last week was pain in the pocketbook, actual or expected, from sinking incomes, lost jobs, failing businesses, higher fuel prices and rising taxes. Even more disturbing than the perceived pain was a...
docs.lead_paragraph: ONE big reason for the angry mood of many voters last week was pain in the pocketbook, actual or expected, from sinking incomes, lost jobs, failing businesses, higher fuel prices and rising taxes. Even more disturbing than the perceived pain was a gnawing anxiety that the American economy might be headed not just for another brief recession, the 10th of the post-World War II period, but for a real depression. Despite the headaches that are the hangover of the wild excesses of the 1980's, the United States economy has not yet cracked, nor is it inevitable that it will. But those who believe that anxiety is warranted say the nation's weakened financial structure might buckle if the economy goes into steep decline. James J. O'Leary, economic consultant to the United States Trust Company of New York, ticks off some major areas of stress:

headline.main: The Nation: Measuring the Pain; Why It's Too Soon To Predict Another Great Depression

docs.snippet: INTERNATIONAL A3-15    Is America ready for war with Iraq? Politicians avoided discussing U.S. policy in the Persian Gulf during the election, but now that nearly 400,000 troops are to be in the region, the wisdom of combat there is being debated...
docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Is America ready for war with Iraq? Politicians avoided discussing U.S. policy in the Persian Gulf during the election, but now that nearly 400,000 troops are to be in the region, the wisdom of combat there is being debated with new vigor. Page A1 The decision not to rotate U.S. troops puts the country on too fast a track toward war in the Persian Gulf, said Senator Sam Nunn, a defense expert, criticizing President Bush's recent military order. The U.S. has asked for this change to give American goods a new outlet in Japan. B9 President Bush's judicial nominees are overwhelmingly white, male and wealthy, according to a report by a liberal lobbying group. His last nominee, just approved by the Senate, is aCongressional aide with little courtroom experience. A woman student says she was raped at the party and another student killed himself shortly before being questioned about what he saw at the party. docs.snippet: After years of intransigence, and only weeks before the Uruguay Round of international trade talks is scheduled to end, the European Community offered last week to trim its protectionist farm policies. The European leaders did not offer much in the...
docs.lead_paragraph: After years of intransigence, and only weeks before the Uruguay Round of international trade talks is scheduled to end, the European Community offered last week to trim its protectionist farm policies. The European leaders did not offer much in the way of concessions. But the proposal will at least keep the trade talks alive. Third world exporting nations threatened to pull out of the talks if industrialized nations refused to let in more food and textiles. In exchange for greater access, the third world would negotiate new rules -- important to the developed nations -- governing trade in agriculture, services and intellectual property. Until last week, the European leaders -- primarily at the insistence of the French and Germans -- had refused to budge.

headline.main: Finally, a Little Courage on Trade

docs.snippet: Talks to liberalize world trade were threatened with collapse today in an impasse over the subsidies that the European Community gives its farmers.   The community made an offer to reduce those subsidies, but the United States, Australia and other...
docs.lead_paragraph: Talks to liberalize world trade were threatened with collapse today in an impasse over the subsidies that the European Community gives its farmers. The community made an offer to reduce those subsidies, but the United States, Australia and other countries that depend on farm exports said the proposal was too meager to talk about. These nations contend that for domestic political reasons, Germany and France in particular subsidize inefficient small farms and encourage them to dump their products on world markets and preserve home markets for themselves.

headline.main: FREE-TRADE TALKS IMPERILED BY FIGHT ON FARM SUBSIDIES
